text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text with a central rectangular miniature spanning the column width; wide margins on either side filled with vine-scroll decoration and acanthus leaves; text appears above and below the image in red rubric and black Gothic script.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with decorative flourishes and frequent ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Red is reserved for the divine halo and the flames of Hell, symbolizing both sanctity and torment; green grounds anchor the scene in an earthly setting; white is used for Christ’s robe to denote purity; brown is applied to demonic figures; minimal blue appears in border rules. The pigments are well preserved, with some slight dulling of red vermilion.

content_theme.scene_description: A single scene depicts Christ’s Harrowing of Hell. On the left stands one naked soul awaiting rescue, rendered in pale flesh tone without garment. At center, Christ appears in a long white robe, hands raised in blessing, encircled by a red nimbus. To the right, a rocky cave mouth opens onto a pit of red and orange flames, within which six to seven damned souls writhe. Two horned demons in iron-oxide brown drag additional souls toward the flames. The ground is a verdigris green slope, rising behind Christ and sloping down toward the cave. The figures are rendered in overlapping tiers: Christ and the soul in front, the damned below, and the cave structure framing the right edge. Christ’s robe is uniform white, contrasting sharply with the flickering red flames. The naked soul’s posture is slightly inclined forward, hand extended toward Christ. The damned are seated or kneeling, arms raised in despair. The spatial arrangement is shallow but hierarchical: Christ occupies the focal centre, the soul to be redeemed on the left, and the damned relegated to the fiery pit on the right.

religious: Christ with red halo and white robe

technical_features.material: Calf vellum with smooth, cream-colored surface and uniform thickness; professional parchment preparation evident in even scraping and pumicing.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall good condition; pigments are vivid with minimal oxidation of vermilion and verdigris; slight flaking in red areas; parchment shows minor cockling at margins.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing beneath Christ’s figure under UV light
Raised gesso beneath white of robe for slight relief
Ruling pattern lightly visible in margin for text alignment

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature of the Harrowing of Hell appears in a vernacular theological treatise on the afterlife, likely produced in a collegiate or monastic workshop in northern France during the early 14th century. The use of Old French and a high-quality Gothic textura quadrata hand suggests an audience of educated clerics seeking moral and doctrinal instruction in the vernacular. The crisp, centralized composition—Christ in radiant white flanked by the awaiting soul and the tormented damned—reflects the period’s emphasis on Christ’s salvific authority. Technically, the layered application of lead white over raised gesso demonstrates sophisticated material practice, while the limited palette and flat color fields align with contemporary courtly workshop conventions. Iconographically, the red nimbus unites divine and infernal flames, underscoring Christ’s victory over death and Hell; the cave mouth evokes typological readings of the Old Testament “Bosom of Abraham.” Comparatively, the miniature shares stylistic affinities with Parisian Psalters of the 1320s in its marginal vine scrolls and precise line work. The image thus synthesizes traditional iconography of the Harrowing with a streamlined, didactic composition suited to a teaching manuscript, bridging the devotional and instructional functions of vernacular theological literature.
